results.headline: A Recent History and a Personal Story
results.summary_short: “Making the Boys” is a captivating documentary about the creation of, and reaction to, the breakthrough play “The Boys in the Band.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Making the Boys

results.headline: On the Road, Packing Querulous Erudition
results.summary_short: In Abbas Kiarostami’s “Certified Copy,” a couple (Juliette Binoche and William Shimell) drive through Tuscany arguing about art, representation and authenticity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Certified Copy

results.headline: Radiant Spirit Blossoms in Barren Land
results.summary_short: Cary Joji Fukunaga’s “Jane Eyre,” starring Mia Wasikowska, is a splendid example of how to tackle the daunting duty of turning a beloved work of classic literature into a movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jane Eyre

results.headline: ‘Brotherhood’: Pledge Night Gone Wrong
results.summary_short: Any college presidents who didn’t ban fraternities after “Animal House” came out in 1978 might consider doing so if they happen to see “Brotherhood.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brotherhood

results.headline: ‘Black Death’ and Dark Ages Drama
results.summary_short: As it turns out, no one is without sin in “Black Death,” a grungy, cynical little number from the British director Christopher Smith.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Death

results.headline: What’s Really Beneath Those Manicured Lawns (and Suburban Smiles)
results.summary_short: Eric Mendelsohn’s “3 Backyards” looks at the secrets and lies seething under the surface of a Long Island town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3 Backyards

results.headline: Art, Saved
results.summary_short: In The Desert of Forbidden Art,” the filmmakers often let the art do the talking.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Desert of Forbidden Art

results.headline: Subject Is Sex (Sort Of), Milieu Is Zany (Sort Of)
results.summary_short: “Elektra Luxx,” a mystifyingly zany comedy directed by Sebastian Gutierrez, is awash in subplots and porn stars.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elektra Luxx

results.headline: The Girl Who Sighed Wolf
results.summary_short: Catherine Hardwicke’s “Red Riding Hood” is a goofily amusing screen fairy tale that includes bloodshed, but it’s generally tamer than its often-gruesome source.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Riding Hood

results.headline: Cheating on His Fiancée With a Camera
results.summary_short: In Dana Adam Shapiro’s “Monogamy,” a seemingly happy engagement is ripped apart by a man’s voyeurism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monogamy

results.headline: Mars, Moms and More
results.summary_short: Mars, once again, looks to Earth to supplement its female population because, it seems, the women who run Mars think Earth mothers are skilled at child rearing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mars Needs Moms

results.headline: Mafia Madness
results.summary_short: “Kill the Irishman” is an extravagantly corny ode to the collapse of the Cleveland mafia in the 1970s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill the Irishman

results.headline: City of Angels Resists Becoming City of Aliens (the Outer-Space Type)
results.summary_short: “Battle: Los Angeles” follows Marines fending off an attack on the title city.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle: Los Angeles

results.headline: A Patch of Rusty Paradise That Might Be Paved
results.summary_short: Véréna Paravel and J. P. Sniadecki directed “Foreign Parts,” a documentary about a polyglot section of Queens populated with chop shops and junkyards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Foreign Parts

results.headline: A Feisty Singing Gypsy, Right There on Your Lap
results.summary_short: “Carmen in 3D” brings a Royal Opera House performance to theatergoers willing to wear those glasses.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carmen in 3D

results.headline: There’s a New Sheriff in Town, and He’s a Rootin’-Tootin’ Reptile
results.summary_short: “Rango,” directed by Gore Verbinski and featuring the voice of Johnny Depp, delights in paying homage to a wide range of westerns.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rango

results.headline: Creepy People With a Plan, and a Couple on the Run
results.summary_short: Matt Damon and Emily Blunt, in a metaphysical mess, in George Nolfi’s “Adjustment Bureau.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Adjustment Bureau

results.headline: A Band That Fights and Plays
results.summary_short: The not-so-comic violence of “Ex Drummer,” by the first-time Belgian director Koen Mortier, features an aggressive punk rock band.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ex Drummer

results.headline: ’Tween College and What Comes Next
results.summary_short: Topher Grace plays a recent college graduate who returns home and tries to woo his dream girl in Michael Dowse’s “Take Me Home Tonight.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take Me Home Tonight

results.headline: Heads Will Roll
results.summary_short: The South Korean director Kim Jee-woon offers “I Saw the Devil,” an operatically violent revenge fantasy with stunning production values.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Saw the Devil
